IX

To THE SAME Laodicea, 50 mc.

At last, after all, I have read a letter worthy of Appius Claudius—a letter full of kindly feel- ing, eourtesy, and consideration. Evidently the very sight of your urban surroundings has given you back your pristine urbanity. For the letters you sent me en route before you took ship from Asia, one about my vetoing the departure of the legates, the other about the stoppage of the building operations of the Appians,“ I read with much pain. And so, eonscious as I was of my unswerving goodwill towards you, I replied with a touch of temper.
